statement:
[**Theorem -**]{} Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a Banach algebra with identity
element $e$ and $G(\mathcal{A})$ be the set of invertible elements in
$\mathcal{A}$. Let $B_r(x)$ denote the open ball of radius $r$ centered
in $x$.

Then, for all $x \in G(\mathcal{A})$ we have that

$$B_{\|x^{-1}\|^{-1}}(x) \subseteq G(\mathcal{A})$$

and therefore $G(\mathcal{A})$ is open in $\mathcal{A}$.

[**Proof :**]{} Let $x \in G(\mathcal{A})$ and
$y \in B_{\|x^{-1}\|^{-1}}(x)$. We have that

$$\|e-x^{-1}y\| = \|x^{-1}x-x^{-1}y\| = \|x^{-1}(x-y)\| \le \|x^{-1}\|\|x-y\| < \|x^{-1}\|\|x^{-1}\|^{-1} = 1$$

So, by the we conclude that $e-(e-x^{-1}y)$ is invertible, i.e.
$x^{-1}y \in G(\mathcal{A})$.

As $G(\mathcal{A})$ is a group we must have $y \in G(\mathcal{A})$.

So $B_{\|x^{-1}\|^{-1}}(x) \subseteq G(\mathcal{A})$ and the theorem
follows. $\square$
names: invertible elements in a Banach algebra form an open set
